projectDesc.p: Encoded for the Experiencing War web site for the Veterans History Project.

samplingDecl.p: The recording of the interview with Conrad A. Groseclose was digitized.

editorialDecl.p: This transcription was encoded with minimal changes to the original text in an effort to preserve original content and idiosyncrasies of the person interviewed. Period language and terminology are also retained. Encoding is literal with regard to the transcriptionist's capitalization, punctuation, and spelling. Spelling errors are indicated with [sic]; however, recurring errors in spelling within a single document have been marked the first time and not subsequently.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Today is December the 17th, 2002. I am interviewing veteran Conrad A. Groseclose, or Bud. His date of birth is 11/9/26; address, 4591 Camborne Drive, Carmel, Indiana, 46033; place of birth, Indianapolis, Indiana. Bud was in the Army Air Corps in a training division, highest rank, private. His dates of enlistment, January_7, '44, to December_7, '45, and he served in World War II. My name is Leslie Reser. I am with Senator Lugar's office, and I will be conducting the interview. Bud, were you drafted or did you enlist?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: No, I enlisted.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: You enlisted. Where were you living at the time?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Mount Comfort, Indiana.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: And why did you join?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Well, first of all, I wanted to learn to fly. I don't know that that's number one, but that was very important to me, and the fact that we were in a war, and I thought it was my duty to be a part of it.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: And which branch of service did you join?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: The Army Air Corps.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Do you recall your first days in the service?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes. I spent several months at Clemson College in South Carolina in an ASTRP program. Having been raised as a farm kid in a little town, I had never been away from home, and it was a rather shocking experience to go to a strange place and not know anybody.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Uh-hum.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: But, it ended up working out fine.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: What kind of training program was it?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: It was a specialized training program for air cadets.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Okay. And how long were you there?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: I was there until February of 1945 I do believe.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: What kind of things did you learn there? Was it a kind of a boot camp?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: No, no, it was strictly a college program, advanced program. We took like 30 college hours in three months, every three months. It was very, very highly specialized in such things as math, physics, chemistry, which I must admit I failed, having never had chemistry before that school.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: That's a tough one. It is.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: It was for me. But, that was the program.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Do you remember any of your instructors or any of the folks you went through this program with?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Oh, I had a very close friend, Jim Dooley, from Wallen, Indiana. We used to converse. I haven't seen him now in years, but he was best man at my wedding after the war was over.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Was he?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: I remember Captain Earnesty (ph), who was our commander, and the head of the school -- it was a military school -- the head of the school was Colonel Cunningham. Why I remember all those, I don't know, but I do. That's_...

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: So you went into the Air Corps January_7, '44?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: And, you stayed at Clemson for about three months you thought?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: No, no. I was there -- We took 30 hours of class every three months.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: I was there until February.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Until February.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Of the following year.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: And what was the ultimate goal then at the end of this? That you would fly?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes. Yes.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Did you actually do any air hours? Were you actually flying planes?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Not there, no. The closest airfield was at Greenville, South Carolina, and we would go over there occasionally, but the only flying I attempted to do was on New Year's Eve of 1944-45. We were going to go with a crew to Bermuda. We got to the end of the runway in a B-25 and lost oil pressure, so we taxied back to the hangar and I spent New Year's Eve in Greenville. It wasn't what I had in mind at all.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: So World War_II is going on at this time.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: And, but you never got to go overseas or see any action?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Did the war end? Is that what happened?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: We went from there to Texas, to -- and I think I told you Wichita Falls. It was in Wichita Falls, but the airfield was Shepherd Field, and the war ended in Europe about that time, and I can't be exact on the date, but in any event, we got the sad news that those of us who had not gotten as far as advanced training in the air program were going to be washed out of the cadet program. So, from there I went to Lowry Field to gunnery school. It was the closest thing I could get to flying without being in a cockpit.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Yeah. How long was gunnery school?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Oh, my, two months or abouts.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Lowry Field you said was in Colorado.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes, in a suburb of Denver. Not there anymore.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Tell me a few of your most memorable experiences. I like the story you just told about New Year's Eve.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Oh, my. Well, I guess no reflection on Clemson, I have been back to visit since then and it's changed considerably, but it was strictly a military school, and I wasn't too fond of the people who were going there that went into the service, but having been raised on a farm where our food was the best, to go to a school like that where -- bear with me -- the floor would be covered at night with cockroaches. It was horrible. It was dirty. The food was lousy. We got a lot of grits. Three meals a day we were served grits. I went from 170 pounds -- and I was not fat -- to when I left service I weighed 125.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Wow.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: And I attributed most of it to --

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: The grits?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: -- the food at Clemson. The grits.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: We Hoosiers are used to grits, aren't we?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: No. I can eat them today.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: You eat them?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Oh, yes I do. I eat grits with butter, salt and pepper. And I couldn't do it for years. Another -- Most of the things are going to be food experiences, but Texas, our favorite food was Diablo stew, and it was made with mutton.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Oh, really.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: And I will not touch a piece of lamb anymore because of that. I mentioned my friend Jim Dooley who, as I say, I haven't seen in years now, and it's my fault. Well, his too. We just don't do it. But, he and I were together almost entire military career.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Were you?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: We went to Clemson together. We didn't know each other before. We went to Clemson before. He was a farm kid, also. We both played basketball in high school. We played at Clemson. We taught some of the southerners how to fast break, that they didn't know how to do. But, he went to Texas with me, and then from there -- he was also in the cadet program -- from there we went to Colorado together, and we separated at that point because he went into -- why, I don't know -- he went into photography school, which I mean, it's fine if that's what he wanted to do, but I could not quite understand that. But, as I say, after the war, after I married and he married, we just kind of drifted apart, so ...

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: How did you keep in touch with your family while you were away from Indiana?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Primarily by letter.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Uh-hum.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: We lived in a little community that had very poor telephone service. Not because of the operator, because the lady who ran the switchboard in Mount Comfort, which was a little house no bigger than this one, was my sister, my older sister.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Oh, really.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: So when I would call home, I would not only get to talk to my parents, but I could also talk to her, because she stayed in on the phone conversation.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: I see.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: But it was seldom we talked by phone. It was mostly by letter.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Mostly by letter. Did you know your wife prior to going into the service?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes, I did. I dated her before I went in the service.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: So you must have kept in touch with her, too, then.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes, I did. In fact, I farmed her parents' farm before I went in the service.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: I see.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: That's how we met.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: I see. So, how did you entertain yourselves? You talked about basketball.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Well, there wasn't much entertainment at Clemson, so I won't mention that. At Shepherd Field, there wasn't much there, either. Wichita Falls -- and I have been through there many times since then going to California, and it has grown considerably and it's a very nice little city, but when I was there, there was only one tree between the air base and the town.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: One tree?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: One tree. There was mesquite, which is a little bush about so big, but as far as a tree like we are used to here, only one. Didn't go to town very often. And, Denver, I became permanent party, which I was a permanent fixture on the field, if I may use that terminology, so I could come and go as I pleased. And of course we didn't make much, 50 bucks a month, so I worked part time as a bowling alley pin boy. You know, I worked for a while, then bowled for a while.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Bowled for a while.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yeah. So that was the main thing that we did.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Did you continue to bowl after the service?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Very much so, yeah. In fact, at one point I considered turning pro.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Did you really.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Uh-hum, but couldn't afford it.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Uh-huh.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Plus, I had a family to support at the time, so ...

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Right. So, do you recall the day your service ended?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Well, yes. It was Pearl Harbor day.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: So, it was the day that I will never forget for many reasons, but --

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: But you knew you were getting out?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes. I was supposed to get out earlier, and my folks' house burned down and my mother was injured with smoke inhalation, and so the Red Cross gave me an emergency leave, so I came home on leave in November, and Jim Dooley was discharged while I was home, so I went back and was discharged a little later.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: I see.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: But --

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Well, that must have been traumatic.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: To have your home burn down.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: So what did you do in the days and weeks afterwards then when you were discharged?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Well, I came home and I went to work. I didn't know about the 52/20 club. You probably never heard of that.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: What's the 52/20 club? I haven't heard it referred to as that anyway.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Well, it was a 52/20 club, and it was for veterans -- they should never have done it -- but it was for veterans. They could draw $20 a week for 52 weeks without working.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Which is ridiculous. But, I didn't know about it, so I didn't draw it. My parents at that point were living in Indianapolis after the fire, and sold the farm and so forth, assuming I would not farm afterwards, which they were right, I wouldn't. So, I went to work for a machinery company called McQuay-Norris. I don't even know that it's still there. It was on Massachusetts Avenue. Worked there for a short while. Wasn't the thing to do. So then I went to work at Fort Harrison, at their disciplinary barracks, and following that back to school.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: You used the GI Bill then?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Did your schooling that you did at Clemson help you in any way?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yes, it did to a point, yeah, because there were many courses I didn't have to take.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: That, and I didn't attempt to take chemistry.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: I don't blame you. I don't blame you.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: And unfortunately I never finished. I got sick and had to quit school, and so I didn't finish.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Where did you go to school?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Indiana.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Indiana University?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yeah. Indianapolis campus.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Got you.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Which was on -- at that time, on East Michigan Street.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Between Pennsylvania and Delaware.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: But -- and I have been sorry on occasion that I didn't finish, but that's a long time ago.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Uh-hum.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: I am not worried about it now. So, then I went to work for Indiana Bell and was there 39 years.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Were you?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Uh-hum. Very good. How did your service and your experiences affect your life? Were you glad you had that year?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Oh, yes. Almost two years; 23 months.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: The old saying, I wouldn't give a nickel to do it again, but I wouldn't give a million dollars for not having the experience. It makes you grow up. I am not sure, I have got three grandsons, none of which -- none of whom are old enough to go in the service yet, but I don't think it would hurt any of them. I don't think it hurts anybody. I really don't.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: What kind of things does it teach you?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: How to do things on your own, you don't have to rely on people. I don't mean that in the wrong way, because I was a manager for many, many years, and I had to rely on my people. They have to do the job for you.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Right. Right.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: But, you know, it teaches you a degree of independence, and tells you a little bit about life.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Uh-hum. Probably teaches you discipline.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Oh, no question about that, yeah. Sure does, yeah.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Yeah. Was there anything else that we haven't covered that you would like to talk about?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: I can't think of anything. My service was, you know, not very_colorful.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Well, like you said, it made a difference in your life.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Absolutely.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: You were part of the whole picture.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: I probably would have ended up being a poor farmer out in Hancock County had I not gone in the service, had there not been a war, but ...

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Kind of opened up your view of the world a little more?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yeah, I think so. And I think of my brother, who is older than I was, who tried to get in the service and was unable to because he had very bad eyes, and I think it affected him the wrong way, you know. He took a very sour look on things. His entire life was -- I mean, he was successful, but he was also miserable, and --

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: You think that had something to do with it?

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Oh, I am sure it did. I am sure it did, yeah. And perhaps some, too, our lack of relationship, because I wouldn't say it was jealousy, but it could be.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: You experienced something that he couldn't.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: So, as I say, I wouldn't have given it up for anything, and I think many, many boys ought to do it. And today girls, too. Sorry.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: I would agree with you.

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: I appreciate your time today, and taking time to record your story --

sp.speaker: Conrad A. Groseclose
sp.p: No problem, such as it is.

sp.speaker: Lesley Reser
sp.p: -- and helping with the Veterans History Project. Thank you very much.
(End of interview.)
